Learning From Compressed Observations

Maxim Raginsky Beckman Institute and University of Illinois
405 N Mathews Ave, Urbana, IL 61801
maxim@uiuc.edu
Abstract

The problem of statistical learning is to construct a predictor of a random variable Y𝑌Y as a function of a related random variable X𝑋X on the basis of an i.i.d. training sample from the joint distribution of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y). Allowable predictors are drawn from some specified class, and the goal is to approach asymptotically the performance (expected loss) of the best predictor in the class. We consider the setting in which one has perfect observation of the X𝑋X-part of the sample, while the Y𝑌Y-part has to be communicated at some finite bit rate. The encoding of the Y𝑌Y-values is allowed to depend on the X𝑋X-values. Under suitable regularity conditions on the admissible predictors, the underlying family of probability distributions and the loss function, we give an information-theoretic characterization of achievable predictor performance in terms of conditional distortion-rate functions. The ideas are illustrated on the example of nonparametric regression in Gaussian noise.

I Introduction and problem statement

Let X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y be jointly distributed random variables, where X𝑋X takes values in an input space 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} and Y𝑌Y takes values in an output space 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y}. The problem of statistical learning is about constructing an accurate predictor of Y𝑌Y as a function of X𝑋X on the basis of some number of independent copies of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y), often with very little or no prior knowledge of the underlying distribution. A very general decision-theoretic framework for learning was proposed by Haussler [1]. In a slightly simplified form it goes as follows. Let 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} be a family of probability distributions on 𝒵=𝒳×𝒴𝒵𝒳𝒴{\cal Z}={\cal X}\times{\cal Y}. Each member P𝑃P of 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} represents a possible relationship between X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y. Also given are a loss function ℓ:𝒴×𝒴→ℝ+:ℓ→𝒴𝒴superscriptℝ\ell:{\cal Y}\times{\cal Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{+} and a set ℱℱ{\cal F} of functions (hypotheses) from 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} into 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y}. For any f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F} and any P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P} we have the expected loss (or risk)

L​(f,P)=𝔼⁡ℓ​(f​(X),Y)≡∫𝒵ℓ​(f​(x),y)​𝑑P​(x,y),𝐿𝑓𝑃𝔼ℓ𝑓𝑋𝑌subscript𝒵ℓ𝑓𝑥𝑦differential-d𝑃𝑥𝑦L(f,P)=\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell(f(X),Y)\equiv\int_{\cal Z}\ell(f(x),y)dP(x,y),

which expresses quantitatively the average performance of f𝑓f as a predictor of Y𝑌Y from X𝑋X when (X,Y)∼Psimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝑃(X,Y)\sim P. Let us define the minimum expected loss

L∗​(ℱ,P)=△inff∈ℱL​(f,P)superscript△superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃subscriptinfimum𝑓ℱ𝐿𝑓𝑃L^{*}({\cal F},P)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\inf_{f\in{\cal F}}L(f,P)

and assume that the infimum is achieved by some f∗∈ℱsuperscript𝑓ℱf^{*}\in{\cal F}. Then f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} is the best predictor of Y𝑌Y from X𝑋X in the hypothesis class ℱℱ{\cal F} when (X,Y)∼Psimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝑃(X,Y)\sim P. The problem of statistical learning is to construct, for each n𝑛n, an approximation to f∗superscript𝑓f^{*} on the basis of a training sequence {Zi}i=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑍𝑖𝑛𝑖1\{Z_{i}\}^{n}_{i=1}, where Zi=(Xi,Yi)subscript𝑍𝑖subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖Z_{i}=(X_{i},Y_{i}) are i.i.d. according to P𝑃P, such that this approximation gets better and better as the sample size n𝑛n tends to infinity. This formulation of the learning problem is referred to as agnostic (or model-free) learning, reflecting the fact that typically only minimal assumptions are made on the causal relation between X𝑋X and Y𝑌Y and on the capability of the hypotheses in ℱℱ{\cal F} to capture this relation. It is general enough to cover such problems as classification, regression and density estimation.

Formally, a learning algorithm (or learner, for short) is a sequence {f^n}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{\widehat{f}_{n}\}^{\infty}_{n=1} of maps f^n:𝒵n×𝒳→𝒴:subscript^𝑓𝑛→superscript𝒵𝑛𝒳𝒴\widehat{f}_{n}:{\cal Z}^{n}\times{\cal X}\rightarrow{\cal Y}, such that f^n​(Zn,⋅)∈ℱsubscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑍𝑛⋅ℱ\widehat{f}_{n}(Z^{n},\cdot)\in{\cal F} for all n𝑛n and all Zn∈𝒵nsuperscript𝑍𝑛superscript𝒵𝑛Z^{n}\in{\cal Z}^{n}. Let Z=(X,Y)∼P𝑍𝑋𝑌similar-to𝑃Z=(X,Y)\sim P be independent of the training sequence Znsuperscript𝑍𝑛Z^{n}. The main quantity of interest is the generalization error of the learner,

L​(f^n,P)𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃\displaystyle L(\widehat{f}_{n},P) =△superscript△\displaystyle\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}} 𝔼⁡[ℓ​(f^n​(Zn,X),Y)|Zn]𝔼conditionalℓsubscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑍𝑛𝑋𝑌superscript𝑍𝑛\displaystyle\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\Big{[}\ell\big{(}\widehat{f}_{n}(Z^{n},X),Y\big{)}\Big{|}Z^{n}\Big{]}
≡\displaystyle\equiv ∫𝒵ℓ​(f^n​(Zn,x),y)​𝑑P​(x,y).subscript𝒵ℓsubscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑍𝑛𝑥𝑦differential-d𝑃𝑥𝑦\displaystyle\int_{\cal Z}\ell(\widehat{f}_{n}(Z^{n},x),y)dP(x,y).

The generalization error is a random variable, as it depends on the training sequence Znsuperscript𝑍𝑛Z^{n}. One is chiefly interested in the asymptotic probabilistic behavior of the excess loss L​(f^n,P)−L∗​(ℱ,P)𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)-L^{*}({\cal F},P) as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty. (Clearly, L​(f^n,P)≥L∗​(ℱ,P)𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\geq L^{*}({\cal F},P) for every n𝑛n.) Under suitable conditions on the loss function ℓℓ\ell, the hypothesis class ℱℱ{\cal F}, and the underlying family 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} of probability distributions, one can show that there exist learning algorithms which not only generalize, i.e., 𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)→L∗​(ℱ,P)→𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\to L^{*}({\cal F},P) as n→∞→𝑛n\to\infty for every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P} (which is the least one could ask for), but are also probably approximately correct (PAC), i.e.

limn→∞P(Zn:L(f^n,P)>L∗(ℱ,P)+ϵ)=0\lim_{n\to\infty}P\left(Z^{n}:L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)>L^{*}({\cal F},P)+\epsilon\right)=0 (1)

for every ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0 and every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}. (See, e.g., Vidyasagar [2].)

This formulation assumes that the training data are available to the learner with arbitrary precision. This assumption may not always hold, however. For example, the location at which the training data are gathered may be geographically separated from the location where the learning actually takes place. Therefore, the training data may have to be communicated to the learner over a channel of finite capacity. In that case, the learner will see only a quantized version of the training data, and must be able to cope with this to the extent allowed by the fundamental limitations imposed by rate-distortion theory. In this paper, we consider a special case of such learning under rate constraints, when the learner has perfect observation of the input part Xn=(X1,…,Xn)superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) of the training sequence, while the output part Yn=(Y1,…,Yn)superscript𝑌𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) has to be communicated via a noiseless digital channel whose capacity is R𝑅R bits per sample. This situation, shown in Figure 1, may arise, for example, in remote sensing, where the Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}’s are the locations of the sensors and the Yisubscript𝑌𝑖Y_{i}’s are the measurements of the sensors having the form f0​(Xi)+Zisubscript𝑓0subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑍𝑖f_{0}(X_{i})+Z_{i}, where f0:𝒳→[0,1]:subscript𝑓0→𝒳01f_{0}:{\cal X}\rightarrow[0,1] is some unknown function and the Zisubscript𝑍𝑖Z_{i}’s are i.i.d. zero-mean Gaussian random variables with variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Assuming that the sensors are dispersed at random over some bounded spatial region 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} and the location of each sensor is known following its deployment, the task of the sensor array is to deliver, over a rate-limited channel, an approximation Y^nsuperscript^𝑌𝑛\widehat{Y}^{n} of the measurement vector Yn=(Y1,…,Yn)superscript𝑌𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) to some central location, where the vector Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} of the sensor locations and the compressed version Y^nsuperscript^𝑌𝑛\widehat{Y}^{n} of the sensor measurements will be fed into a learner that will approximate f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} by some function f^n​(Xn,Y^n,⋅)subscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛⋅\widehat{f}_{n}(X^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n},\cdot) from a given hypothesis class ℱℱ{\cal F}.

In this paper, we establish information-theoretic upper bounds on the achievable generalization error in this setting. In particular, we relate the problem of agnostic learning under (partial) rate constraints to conditional rate-distortion theory [3, Section 6.1], [4], [5, Appendix A], which is concerned with lossy source coding in the presence of side information both at the encoder and at the decoder. In the set-up shown in Figure 1, the input part Xn=(X1,…,Xn)superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑋1…subscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}=(X_{1},\ldots,X_{n}) of the training sequence, which is available both to the encoder and to the decoder (hence to the learner), plays the role of the side information, while the output part Yn=(Y1,…,Yn)superscript𝑌𝑛subscript𝑌1…subscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n}=(Y_{1},\ldots,Y_{n}) is to be coded using a lossy source code operating at the rate of R𝑅R bits per symbol. Furthermore, because the distribution of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) is known only to be a member of some family 𝒫𝒫{\cal P}, the lossy codes must be robust in the presence of this uncertainty.

Let us formally state the problem. Let 𝒫,ℱ,ℓ𝒫ℱℓ{\cal P},{\cal F},\ell be given. A scheme for agnostic learning under partial rate constraints (from now on, simply a scheme) operating at rate R𝑅R is specified by a sequence of triples {(en,dn,f^n)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1}, where en:𝒳n×𝒴n→{1,…,2n​R}:subscript𝑒𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛superscript𝒴𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅e_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times{\cal Y}^{n}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\} is the encoder, dn:𝒳n×{1,…,2n​R}→𝒴n:subscript𝑑𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅superscript𝒴𝑛d_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\}\rightarrow{\cal Y}^{n} is the decoder, and f^n:𝒳n×𝒴n→ℱ:subscript^𝑓𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛superscript𝒴𝑛ℱ\widehat{f}_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times{\cal Y}^{n}\rightarrow{\cal F} is the learner. We shall often abuse notation and let f^nsubscript^𝑓𝑛\widehat{f}_{n} denote also the function f^n​(Xn,Y^n,⋅)subscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛⋅\widehat{f}_{n}(X^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n},\cdot). For each n𝑛n, the output of the learner is a hypothesis f^n​(Xn,Y^n,⋅)∈ℱsubscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛⋅ℱ\widehat{f}_{n}(X^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n},\cdot)\in{\cal F}, where Y^n=dn​(Xn,en​(Xn,Yn))superscript^𝑌𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑒𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛\widehat{Y}^{n}=d_{n}(X^{n},e_{n}(X^{n},Y^{n})) is the reproduction of Ynsuperscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n} given the side information Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}. For any P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}, the main object of interest associated with the scheme is the generalization error

L​(f^n,P)=△𝔼⁡[ℓ​(f^n​(Xn,Y^n,X),Y)|Xn,Yn],superscript△𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃𝔼conditionalℓsubscript^𝑓𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛𝑋𝑌superscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\Big{[}\ell\big{(}\widehat{f}_{n}(X^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n},X),Y\big{)}\Big{|}X^{n},Y^{n}\Big{]},

where (X,Y)∼Psimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝑃(X,Y)\sim P is assumed independent of {(Xi,Yi)}i=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖𝑛𝑖1\{(X_{i},Y_{i})\}^{n}_{i=1} (to keep the notation simple, we suppress the dependence of the generalization error on the encoder and the decoder). In particular, we are interested in the achievable values of the asymptotic expected excess risk. We say that a pair (R,Δ)𝑅Δ(R,\Delta) is achievable for (ℱ,𝒫,ℓ)ℱ𝒫ℓ({\cal F},{\cal P},\ell) if there exists a scheme {(en,dn,f^n)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1} operating at rate R𝑅R, such that

lim supn→∞𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≤L∗​(ℱ,P)+Δsubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃Δ\limsup_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\leq L^{*}({\cal F},P)+\Delta

for every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}. After listing the basic assumptions in Sec. II, we derive in Sec. III sufficient conditions for (R,Δ)𝑅Δ(R,\Delta) to be achievable. We then apply our results to the setting of nonparametric regression in Sec. IV. Discussion of results and an outline of future directions are given in Sec. V.

I-A Related work

Previously, the problem of statistical estimation from compressed data was considered by Zhang and Berger [6], Ahlswede and Burnashev [7] and Han and Amari [8] from the viewpoint of multiterminal information theory. In these papers, the underlying family of distributions of (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) is parametric, i.e., of the form 𝒫={Pθ}θ∈Θ𝒫subscriptsubscript𝑃𝜃𝜃Θ{\cal P}=\{P_{\theta}\}_{\theta\in\Theta}, where ΘΘ\Theta is a subset of ℝksuperscriptℝ𝑘\mathbb{R}^{k} for some finite k𝑘k, and one wishes to estimate the “true” parameter θ∗superscript𝜃\theta^{*}. The i.i.d. observations {(Xi,Yi)}i=1nsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑌𝑖𝑛𝑖1\{(X_{i},Y_{i})\}^{n}_{i=1} are drawn from Pθ∗subscript𝑃superscript𝜃P_{\theta^{*}}, and the input part Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n} is communicated to the statistician at some rate R1subscript𝑅1R_{1}, while the output part Ynsuperscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n} is communicated at some rate R2subscript𝑅2R_{2}. The present work generalizes to the nonparametric setting the case considered by Ahlswede and Burnashev [7], namely when R1=∞subscript𝑅1R_{1}=\infty. To the best of the author’s knowledge, this paper is the first to consider the problem of nonparametric learning from compressed observations with side information.

II Assumptions

We begin by stating some basic assumptions on ℱℱ{\cal F}, 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} and ℓℓ\ell. Additional assumptions will be listed in the sequel as needed.

The input space 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} is taken to be a measurable subset of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}, while the output space is either a finite set (as in classification) or the set of reals ℝℝ\mathbb{R} (as in regression or function estimation). We assume throughout that the family 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} of distributions on 𝒳×𝒴𝒳𝒴{\cal X}\times{\cal Y} is such that the mutual information I​(X;Y)<∞𝐼𝑋𝑌I(X;Y)<\infty for every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}. All information-theoretic quantities will be in bits, unless specified otherwise.

We assume that there exists a learning algorithm which generalizes optimally in the absence of any rate constraints. Therefore, our standing assumption on (ℱ,𝒫,ℓ)ℱ𝒫ℓ({\cal F},{\cal P},\ell) will be that the induced function class ℒℱ={ℓf:f∈ℱ}subscriptℒℱconditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑓𝑓ℱ{\cal L}_{\cal F}=\{\ell_{f}:f\in{\cal F}\}, where ℓf​(z)=△ℓ​(f​(x),y)superscript△subscriptℓ𝑓𝑧ℓ𝑓𝑥𝑦\ell_{f}(z)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\ell(f(x),y) for all z=(x,y)∈𝒵𝑧𝑥𝑦𝒵z=(x,y)\in{\cal Z}, satisfies the uniform law of large numbers (ULLN) for every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}, i.e.,

supf∈ℱ|1n​∑i=1nℓf​(Zi)−𝔼⁡ℓf​(Z)|→0,a.s.formulae-sequence→subscriptsupremum𝑓ℱ1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscriptℓ𝑓subscript𝑍𝑖𝔼subscriptℓ𝑓𝑍0as\sup_{f\in{\cal F}}\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\ell_{f}(Z_{i})-\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{f}(Z)\right|\to 0,\qquad\rm{a.s.} (2)

where Z,Z1,Z2,…𝑍subscript𝑍1subscript𝑍2…Z,Z_{1},Z_{2},\ldots are i.i.d. according to P𝑃P. Eq. (2) implies that, for any sequence {fn}⊂ℱsubscript𝑓𝑛ℱ\{f_{n}\}\subset{\cal F},

|1n​∑i=1nℓfn​(Zi)−𝔼⁡ℓfn​(Z)|→0,a.s.formulae-sequence→1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscriptℓsubscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑍𝑖𝔼subscriptℓsubscript𝑓𝑛𝑍0as\left|\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\ell_{f_{n}}(Z_{i})-\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{f_{n}}(Z)\right|\to 0,\qquad\rm{a.s.}

This holds even in the case when each fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is random, i.e., fn​(⋅)=fn​(Zn,⋅)subscript𝑓𝑛⋅subscript𝑓𝑛superscript𝑍𝑛⋅f_{n}(\cdot)=f_{n}(Z^{n},\cdot). The ULLN is a standard ingredient in proofs of consistency of learning algorithms: if (ℱ,𝒫,ℓ)ℱ𝒫ℓ({\cal F},{\cal P},\ell) are such that (2) holds, then the Empirical Risk Minimization algorithm (ERM), given by

f^n=arg​minf∈ℱ⁡1n​∑i=1nℓf​(Zi),subscript^𝑓𝑛subscriptargmin𝑓ℱ1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1subscriptℓ𝑓subscript𝑍𝑖\widehat{f}_{n}=\operatornamewithlimits{arg\,min}_{f\in{\cal F}}\frac{1}{n}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\ell_{f}(Z_{i}),

is PAC in the sense of (1) [2, Theorem 3.2].

Next, we assume that the loss function ℓℓ\ell has the following “generalized Lipschitz” property: there exists a concave, continuous function η:ℝ+→ℝ+:𝜂→superscriptℝsuperscriptℝ\eta:\mathbb{R}^{+}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{+}, such that for all f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F}, x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in{\cal X} and u,u′∈𝒴𝑢superscript𝑢′𝒴u,u^{\prime}\in{\cal Y}

|ℓ​(f​(x),u)−ℓ​(f​(x),u′)|≤η​(ℓ​(u,u′)).ℓ𝑓𝑥𝑢ℓ𝑓𝑥superscript𝑢′𝜂ℓ𝑢superscript𝑢′\left|\ell(f(x),u)-\ell(f(x),u^{\prime})\right|\leq\eta(\ell(u,u^{\prime})). (3)

This holds, for example, in the following cases:

  • •

    Suppose that ℓℓ\ell is a metric on 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y}. Then, by the triangle inequality we have ℓ​(y,u)≤ℓ​(y,u′)+ℓ​(u′,u)ℓ𝑦𝑢ℓ𝑦superscript𝑢′ℓsuperscript𝑢′𝑢\ell(y,u)\leq\ell(y,u^{\prime})+\ell(u^{\prime},u) for all y,u,u′∈𝒴𝑦𝑢superscript𝑢′𝒴y,u,u^{\prime}\in{\cal Y}, so (3) holds with η​(t)=t𝜂𝑡𝑡\eta(t)=t.

  • •

    Suppose that 𝒴=[0,1]𝒴01{\cal Y}=[0,1] and ℓ​(u,u′)=|u−u′|pℓ𝑢superscript𝑢′superscript𝑢superscript𝑢′𝑝\ell(u,u^{\prime})=|u-u^{\prime}|^{p} for some p≥1𝑝1p\geq 1. Then one can show that

    |ℓ​(f​(x),u)−ℓ​(f​(x),u′)|≤p​|u−u′|ℓ𝑓𝑥𝑢ℓ𝑓𝑥superscript𝑢′𝑝𝑢superscript𝑢′\left|\ell(f(x),u)-\ell(f(x),u^{\prime})\right|\leq p|u-u^{\prime}|

    for all f:𝒳→𝒴:𝑓→𝒳𝒴f:{\cal X}\rightarrow{\cal Y}, x∈𝒳𝑥𝒳x\in{\cal X} and u,u′∈𝒴𝑢superscript𝑢′𝒴u,u^{\prime}\in{\cal Y}, so (3) holds with η​(t)=p​t1/p𝜂𝑡𝑝superscript𝑡1𝑝\eta(t)=pt^{1/p}.

Finally, we need to pose some assumptions on the metric structure of the class 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} with respect to the variational distance [9, Sec. 5.2], which for any two probability distributions P1,P2subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃2P_{1},P_{2} on a measurable space (𝒵,𝒜)𝒵𝒜({\cal Z},{\cal A}) is defined by

dV​(P1,P2)=△2​supA∈𝒜|P1​(A)−P2​(A)|.superscript△subscript𝑑𝑉subscript𝑃1subscript𝑃22subscriptsupremum𝐴𝒜subscript𝑃1𝐴subscript𝑃2𝐴d_{V}(P_{1},P_{2})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}2\sup_{A\in{\cal A}}|P_{1}(A)-P_{2}(A)|.

A finite set {P1,…,PM}⊂𝒫subscript𝑃1…subscript𝑃𝑀𝒫\{P_{1},\ldots,P_{M}\}\subset{\cal P} is called an (internal) ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-net for 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} with respect to dVsubscript𝑑𝑉d_{V} if

supP∈𝒫min1≤m≤M⁡dV​(P,Pm)≤ϵ.subscriptsupremum𝑃𝒫subscript1𝑚𝑀subscript𝑑𝑉𝑃subscript𝑃𝑚italic-ϵ\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}\min_{1\leq m\leq M}d_{V}(P,P_{m})\leq\epsilon.

The cardinality of a minimal ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-net, denoted by N​(ϵ,𝒫)𝑁italic-ϵ𝒫N(\epsilon,{\cal P}), is called the ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-covering number of 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} w.r.t. dVsubscript𝑑𝑉d_{V}, and the Kolmogorov ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-entropy of 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} is defined as H​(ϵ,𝒫)=△log⁡N​(ϵ,𝒫)superscript△𝐻italic-ϵ𝒫𝑁italic-ϵ𝒫H(\epsilon,{\cal P})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\log N(\epsilon,{\cal P}) [10]. We assume that the class 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} satisfies Dobrushin’s entropy condition [11], i.e., for every c>0𝑐0c>0

limϵ→0H​(ϵ,𝒫)2c/ϵ=0.subscript→italic-ϵ0𝐻italic-ϵ𝒫superscript2𝑐italic-ϵ0\lim_{\epsilon\to 0}\frac{H(\epsilon,{\cal P})}{2^{c/\epsilon}}=0. (4)

This condition is satisfied, for example, in the following cases: (1) 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} and 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y} are both finite sets; (2) 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} is a finite family; (3) 𝒵𝒵{\cal Z} is a compact subset of a Euclidean space, and all P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P} are absolutely continuous with densities satisfying a uniform Lipschitz condition [10, 11].

III The results

To state our results we shall need some notions from conditional rate-distortion theory [3, Sec. 6.1], [4], [5, Appendix A]. Fix some P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}. Given a pair (X,Y)∼Psimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝑃(X,Y)\sim P and a nonnegative real number D𝐷D, define the set ℳ​(D)ℳ𝐷{\cal M}(D) to consist of all 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y}-valued random variables Y^^𝑌\widehat{Y} jointly distributed with (X,Y)𝑋𝑌(X,Y) and satisfying the constraint 𝔼⁡ℓ​(Y,Y^)≤D𝔼ℓ𝑌^𝑌𝐷\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell(Y,\hat{Y})\leq D, where the expectation is taken with respect to the joint distribution of X,Y,Y^𝑋𝑌^𝑌X,Y,\widehat{Y}. Then the conditional rate-distortion function of Y𝑌Y given X𝑋X w.r.t. P𝑃P is defined by

RY|X(D,P)=△inf{I(Y;Y^|X):Y^∈ℳ(D)},R_{Y|X}(D,P)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\inf\left\{I(Y;\widehat{Y}|X):\widehat{Y}\in{\cal M}(D)\right\},

where I​(Y;Y^|X)𝐼𝑌conditional^𝑌𝑋I(Y;\widehat{Y}|X) is the conditional mutual information between Y𝑌Y and Y^^𝑌\widehat{Y} given X𝑋X. Our assumption that I​(X;Y)<∞𝐼𝑋𝑌I(X;Y)<\infty ensures the existence of RY|X​(D,P)subscript𝑅conditional𝑌𝑋𝐷𝑃R_{Y|X}(D,P) [5]. In operational terms, RY|X​(D,P)subscript𝑅conditional𝑌𝑋𝐷𝑃R_{Y|X}(D,P) is the minimum number of bits needed to describe Y𝑌Y with expected distortion of at most D𝐷D given perfect observation of a correlated random variable X𝑋X (the side information) when (X,Y)∼Psimilar-to𝑋𝑌𝑃(X,Y)\sim P. As a function of D𝐷D, RY|X​(D,P)subscript𝑅conditional𝑌𝑋𝐷𝑃R_{Y|X}(D,P) is convex and strictly decreasing everywhere it is finite, hence it is invertible. The inverse function is called the conditional distortion-rate function of Y𝑌Y given X𝑋X and is denoted by DY|X​(R,P)subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃D_{Y|X}(R,P). Finally, let

𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫)=△supP∈𝒫DY|X​(R,P).superscript△subscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫subscriptsupremum𝑃𝒫subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃{\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P})\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}D_{Y|X}(R,P).

We assume that 𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫)<∞subscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫{\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P})<\infty for all R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0.

We shall also need the following lemma, which can be proved by a straightforward extension of Dobrushin’s random coding argument from [11] to the case of side information available to the encoder and to the decoder:

Lemma III.1

Let 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} satisfy Dobrushin’s entropy condition (4). Assume that the loss function ℓℓ\ell either is bounded or satisfies a uniform moment condition

supP∈𝒫𝔼⁡[ℓ​(Y,y0)1+δ]<∞subscriptsupremum𝑃𝒫𝔼ℓsuperscript𝑌subscript𝑦01𝛿\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}[\ell(Y,y_{0})^{1+\delta}]<\infty (5)

for some δ>0𝛿0\delta>0 with respect to some fixed reference letter y0∈𝒴subscript𝑦0𝒴y_{0}\in{\cal Y}. Then for every rate R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0 there exists a sequence {(en,dn)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1} of encoders en:𝒳n×𝒴n→{1,…,2n​R}:subscript𝑒𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛superscript𝒴𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅e_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times{\cal Y}^{n}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\} and decoders dn:𝒳n×{1,…,2n​R}→𝒴n:subscript𝑑𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅superscript𝒴𝑛d_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\}\rightarrow{\cal Y}^{n}, such that

lim supn→∞supP∈𝒫𝔼⁡ℓn​(Yn,Y^n)≤𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫),subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛subscriptsupremum𝑃𝒫𝔼subscriptℓ𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛subscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫\limsup_{n\to\infty}\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{n}(Y^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n})\leq{\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P}),

where Y^n=dn​(Xn,en​(Xn,Yn))superscript^𝑌𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛subscript𝑒𝑛superscript𝑋𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛\widehat{Y}^{n}=d_{n}(X^{n},e_{n}(X^{n},Y^{n})) and ℓn​(Yn,Y^n)=n−1​∑i=1nℓ​(Yi,Y^i)subscriptℓ𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛superscript𝑛1subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑖1ℓsubscript𝑌𝑖subscript^𝑌𝑖\ell_{n}(Y^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n})=n^{-1}\sum^{n}_{i=1}\ell(Y_{i},\widehat{Y}_{i}) is the normalized cumulative loss between Ynsuperscript𝑌𝑛Y^{n} and Y^nsuperscript^𝑌𝑛\widehat{Y}^{n}.

and

The two leading terms on the right-hand side of this inequality are zero by the ULLN. Moreover, given R𝑅R, Lemma III.1 asserts the existence of a sequence {(en,dn)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1} of encoders en:𝒳n×𝒴n→{1,…,2n​R}:subscript𝑒𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛superscript𝒴𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅e_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times{\cal Y}^{n}\rightarrow\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\} and decoders dn:𝒳n×{1,…,2n​R}→𝒴n:subscript𝑑𝑛→superscript𝒳𝑛1…superscript2𝑛𝑅superscript𝒴𝑛d_{n}:{\cal X}^{n}\times\{1,\ldots,2^{nR}\}\rightarrow{\cal Y}^{n}, such that

lim supn→∞𝔼⁡ℓn​(Yn,Y^n)≤𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫),∀P∈𝒫.formulae-sequencesubscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛𝔼subscriptℓ𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛subscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫for-all𝑃𝒫\limsup_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{n}(Y^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n})\leq{\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P}),\qquad\forall P\in{\cal P}.

Substitution of this into (10) proves the theorem.   

Corollary III.2

All pairs (R,Δ)𝑅Δ(R,\Delta) with Δ≥2​η​(𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫))Δ2𝜂subscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫\Delta\geq 2\eta({\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P})) are achievable.

Remark III.1

In the Appendix, we show that a corresponding lower bound derived by the usual methods for proving converses in lossy source coding is strictly weaker than the “obvious” lower bound based on the observation that 𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≥L∗​(ℱ,P)𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\geq L^{*}({\cal F},P) for any f^nsubscript^𝑓𝑛\widehat{f}_{n}. It may be possible to obtain nontrivial lower bounds in the minimax setting, which we leave for future work (see also Sec. V).

Remark III.2

Under some technical conditions on the function class {ℓf:f∈ℱ}conditional-setsubscriptℓ𝑓𝑓ℱ\{\ell_{f}:f\in{\cal F}\} (see, e.g., [12]), one can show that

𝔼​supf∈ℱ|L^Zn​(f)−L​(f,P)|≤C/n,∀P∈𝒫formulae-sequence𝔼subscriptsupremum𝑓ℱsubscript^𝐿superscript𝑍𝑛𝑓𝐿𝑓𝑃𝐶𝑛for-all𝑃𝒫\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\sup_{f\in{\cal F}}\Big{|}\widehat{L}_{Z^{n}}(f)-L(f,P)\Big{|}\leq C/\sqrt{n},\qquad\forall P\in{\cal P}

for some constant C𝐶C that depends on ℱ,ℓℱℓ{\cal F},\ell. Using this fact and the same bounding method that led to Eq. (10), but without taking the limit superior, we can get the following finite-sample bound for every scheme {(en,dn,f^n)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1} with f^nsubscript^𝑓𝑛\widehat{f}_{n} given by (6) and arbitrary en,dnsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛e_{n},d_{n}:

𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≤L∗​(ℱ,P)+2​η​(𝔼⁡ℓn​(Yn,Y^n))+C′/n,𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃2𝜂𝔼subscriptℓ𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛superscript^𝑌𝑛superscript𝐶′𝑛\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\leq L^{*}({\cal F},P)+2\eta\big{(}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{n}(Y^{n},\widehat{Y}^{n})\big{)}+C^{\prime}/\sqrt{n},

where C′=2​Csuperscript𝐶′2𝐶C^{\prime}=2C.

The following theorem shows that we can replace condition (3) with the requirement that ℓℓ\ell be a power of a metric:

Theorem III.3

Suppose that the loss function ℓℓ\ell is of the form ℓ​(y,u)=d​(y,u)rℓ𝑦𝑢𝑑superscript𝑦𝑢𝑟\ell(y,u)=d(y,u)^{r} for some r≥1𝑟1r\geq 1, where d𝑑d is a metric on 𝒴𝒴{\cal Y}. Then for any rate R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0 the scheme constructed in the proof of Theorem III.1 is such that

holds for every P∈𝒫𝑃𝒫P\in{\cal P}.

Proof: We proceed essentially along the same lines as in the proof of Theorem III.1, except that the bound (7) is replaced with an argument based on Minkowski’s inequality to yield

The rest is immediate using the ULLN as well as concavity and continuity of t↦t1/rmaps-to𝑡superscript𝑡1𝑟t\mapsto t^{1/r} for t≥0𝑡0t\geq 0.   

IV Example: nonparametric regression

As an example, let us consider the setting of nonparametric regression. Let 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} be a compact subset of ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d} and 𝒴=ℝ𝒴ℝ{\cal Y}=\mathbb{R}. The training data are of the form

Yi=f0​(Xi)+Zi,1≤i≤nformulae-sequencesubscript𝑌𝑖subscript𝑓0subscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑍𝑖1𝑖𝑛Y_{i}=f_{0}(X_{i})+Z_{i},\qquad 1\leq i\leq n (11)

where the regression function f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} belongs to some specified class ℱℱ{\cal F} of functions from 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} into [0,1]01[0,1], the Xisubscript𝑋𝑖X_{i}’s are i.i.d. random variables drawn from the uniform distribution on 𝒳𝒳{\cal X}, and the Zisubscript𝑍𝑖Z_{i}’s are i.i.d. zero-mean normal random variables with variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}, independent of Xnsuperscript𝑋𝑛X^{n}. We take ℓ​(y,u)=|y−u|2ℓ𝑦𝑢superscript𝑦𝑢2\ell(y,u)=|y-u|^{2}, the squared loss. Note that ℓℓ\ell satisfies the condition of Theorem III.3 with r=2𝑟2r=2.

Because f0subscript𝑓0f_{0} is unknown, we take as the underlying family 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} the class of all absolutely continuous distributions with densities of the form pf​(x,y)=V−1​𝒩​(y;f​(x),σ2)subscript𝑝𝑓𝑥𝑦superscript𝑉1𝒩𝑦𝑓𝑥superscript𝜎2p_{f}(x,y)=V^{-1}{\cal N}(y;f(x),\sigma^{2}), f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F}, where V𝑉V is the volume of 𝒳𝒳{\cal X} and 𝒩​(y;f​(x),σ2)𝒩𝑦𝑓𝑥superscript𝜎2{\cal N}(y;f(x),\sigma^{2}) is the one-dimensional normal density with mean f​(x)𝑓𝑥f(x) and variance σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}. Because the functions in ℱℱ{\cal F} are bounded between 00 and 111, it is easy to show that the uniform moment condition (5) of Lemma III.1 is satisfied with δ=1𝛿1\delta=1 and y0=0subscript𝑦00y_{0}=0.

We suppose that ℓℓ\ell and ℱℱ{\cal F} are such that the function class ℒℱsubscriptℒℱ{\cal L}_{\cal F} satisfies the ULLN.111See Györfi et al. [13] for a detailed exposition of the various conditions when this is true. Lemma IV.1

If ℱℱ{\cal F} satisfies (12), then 𝒫𝒫{\cal P} satisfies Dobrushin’s entropy condition (4).

Lemma IV.2

For any R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0, 𝔻Y|X​(R,𝒫)=σ2​2−2​Rsubscript𝔻conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝒫superscript𝜎2superscript22𝑅{\mathbb{D}}_{Y|X}(R,{\cal P})=\sigma^{2}2^{-2R}.

Hence DY|X​(R,Pf)subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅subscript𝑃𝑓D_{Y|X}(R,P_{f}) is independent of f𝑓f. Taking the supremum over ℱℱ{\cal F} finishes the proof.  

Now we can state and prove the main result of this section:

Theorem IV.1

Consider the regression setting of (11). Under the stated assumptions, for any R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0 there exists a scheme {(en,dn,f^n)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1}, such that

lim supn→∞𝔼⁡[L​(f^n,Pf)1/2]≤σ​(1+2−R+1)subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛𝔼𝐿superscriptsubscript^𝑓𝑛subscript𝑃𝑓12𝜎1superscript2𝑅1\limsup_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[L(\widehat{f}_{n},P_{f})^{1/2}\right]\leq\sigma(1+2^{-R+1}) (14)

holds for every f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F}.

Proof: As follows from the above, the triple (ℱ,𝒫,ℓ)ℱ𝒫ℓ({\cal F},{\cal P},\ell) satisfies all the assumptions of Theorem III.3. Therefore for any R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0 there exists a scheme {(en,dn,f^n)}n=1∞subscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑛1\{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})\}^{\infty}_{n=1} operating at rate R𝑅R, such that

lim supn→∞𝔼⁡[L​(f^n,Pf)1/2]≤L∗​(ℱ,Pf)1/2+2−R+1​σ,subscriptlimit-supremum→𝑛𝔼𝐿superscriptsubscript^𝑓𝑛subscript𝑃𝑓12superscript𝐿superscriptℱsubscript𝑃𝑓12superscript2𝑅1𝜎\limsup_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\left[L(\widehat{f}_{n},P_{f})^{1/2}\right]\leq L^{*}({\cal F},P_{f})^{1/2}+2^{-R+1}\sigma, (15)

holds for every f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F} (we have also used Lemma IV.2). It is not hard to show that

L​(g,Pf)=‖f−g‖2,Q2+σ2,∀f,g∈ℱ,formulae-sequence𝐿𝑔subscript𝑃𝑓subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝑓𝑔22𝑄superscript𝜎2for-all𝑓𝑔ℱL(g,P_{f})=\|f-g\|^{2}_{2,Q}+\sigma^{2},\qquad\forall f,g\in{\cal F},

whence it follows that L∗​(ℱ,Pf)=σ2superscript𝐿ℱsubscript𝑃𝑓superscript𝜎2L^{*}({\cal F},P_{f})=\sigma^{2} for every f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F}. Substituting this into (15), we get (14).   

V Discussion and future work

We have derived information-theoretic bounds on the achievable generalization error in learning from compressed data (with side information). There is a close relationship between this problem and the theory of robust lossy source coding with side information at the encoder and the decoder. A major difference between this setting and the usual setting of learning theory is that the techniques are no longer distribution-free because restrictions must be placed on the underlying family of distributions in order to guarantee the existence of a suitable source code. The theory was applied to the problem of nonparametric regression in Gaussian noise, where we have shown that the penalty incurred for using compressed observations decays exponentially with the rate.

We have proved Theorems III.1 and III.3 by adopting ERM as our learning algorithm and optimizing the source code to deliver the best possible reconstruction of the training data. In effect, this imposes a separation structure between learning and source coding. While this “modular” approach is simplistic (clearly, additional performance gains could be attained by designing the encoder, the decoder and the learner jointly), it may be justified in such applications as remote sensing. For instance, if the source code and the learner were designed jointly, then any change made to the hypothesis class (say, if we decided to replace the currently used hypothesis class with another based on tracking the prior performance of the network) might call for a complete redesign of the source code and the sensor network, which may be a costly step. With the modular approach, no such redesign is necessary: one merely makes the necessary adjustments in the learning algorithm, while the sensor network continues to operate as before.

Let us close by sketching some directions for future work. First of all, it would be of interest to derive information-theoretic lower bounds on the generalization performance of rate-constrained learning algorithms. In particular, just as Ahlswede and Burnashev had done in the parametric case [7], we could study the asymptotics of the ninimax excess risk

δn​(R)=△inf(en,dn,f^n)supP∈𝒫[𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)−L∗​(ℱ,P)],superscript△subscript𝛿𝑛𝑅subscriptinfimumsubscript𝑒𝑛subscript𝑑𝑛subscript^𝑓𝑛subscriptsupremum𝑃𝒫delimited-[]𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃\delta_{n}(R)\stackrel{{\scriptstyle\scriptscriptstyle\triangle}}{{=}}\inf_{(e_{n},d_{n},\widehat{f}_{n})}\sup_{P\in{\cal P}}\Big{[}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)-L^{*}({\cal F},P)\Big{]},

where the infimum is over all encoders, decoders and learners operating on a length-n𝑛n training sequence at rate R𝑅R. Secondly, we could dispense with the assumption that the learner has perfect observation of the input part of the training sample, in analogy to the situation dealt with by Zhang and Berger [6]. Finally, keeping in mind the motivating example of sensor networks, it would be useful to replace the block coding approach used here with an efficient distributed scheme.

lim infn→∞𝔼⁡ℓn​(Wn,Yn)≥DY|X​(R,P).subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑛𝔼subscriptℓ𝑛superscript𝑊𝑛superscript𝑌𝑛subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃\liminf_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}\ell_{n}(W^{n},Y^{n})\geq D_{Y|X}(R,P).

lim infn→∞𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≥DY|X​(R,P).subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑛𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃\liminf_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\geq D_{Y|X}(R,P). (A.2)

Now, given any f∈ℱ𝑓ℱf\in{\cal F}, we can interpret f​(X)𝑓𝑋f(X) as a zero-rate approximation of Y𝑌Y (using only the side information X𝑋X), so L​(f,P)≥DY|X​(0,P)≥DY|X​(R,P)𝐿𝑓𝑃subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋0𝑃subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃L(f,P)\geq D_{Y|X}(0,P)\geq D_{Y|X}(R,P) for any R≥0𝑅0R\geq 0. lim infn→∞𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≥L∗​(ℱ,P)≥DY|X​(R,P)subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑛𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃subscript𝐷conditional𝑌𝑋𝑅𝑃\liminf_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\geq L^{*}({\cal F},P)\geq D_{Y|X}(R,P)

for all R𝑅R. Thus, the information-theoretic lower bound (A.2) is weaker than the bound lim infn→∞𝔼⁡L​(f^n,P)≥L∗​(ℱ,P)subscriptlimit-infimum→𝑛𝔼𝐿subscript^𝑓𝑛𝑃superscript𝐿ℱ𝑃\liminf\limits_{n\to\infty}\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}L(\widehat{f}_{n},P)\geq L^{*}({\cal F},P).
